TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in Imatra . He was represented before the ORG by PERSON PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government were represented by Mr PERSON , Agent , and Mr PERSON , ORG , both from ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant was charged before ORG ( käräjäoikeus , tingsrätt ) with CARDINAL counts of aggravated fraud and debtor ’s dishonesty . In the same case CARDINAL other defendants were charged with various types of economic offences .

On DATE the court proceedings in ORG commenced . The court was composed of CARDINAL professional presiding judge and CARDINAL lay members . The court heard the defendants and CARDINAL witnesses . The case was adjourned until DATE .
On DATE CARDINAL witnesses gave evidence and the defendants were again heard . The case was adjourned until DATE .
On DATE two witnesses gave evidence and the defendants were again heard . The case was adjourned until DATE .

Meanwhile , the presiding judge was changed and a new judge presided over the hearing on DATE . CARDINAL witness gave evidence . The case was adjourned until DATE , when CARDINAL witness gave evidence and the final statements were presented .

On DATE , ORG found the applicant guilty on CARDINAL count of aggravated fraud and debtor ’s dishonesty . He was sentenced to a suspended term of imprisonment of DATE and DATE and ordered to pay ORG CARDINAL in damages jointly and severally with CARDINAL other defendants . The applicant was acquitted in respect of CARDINAL charges . In so far as the judgment concerned his conviction for debtor ’s dishonesty , the court based itself on documentary evidence and the testimony of CARDINAL of the witnesses heard before the presiding judge was changed . That witness ’s testimony concerned certain banking transactions with which the witness had been charged in her capacity as bank employee .

The applicant appealed to ORG ( hovioikeus , hovrätt ) , requesting an oral hearing . On DATE ORG rejected the request for an oral hearing and upheld the conviction in respect of debtor ’s dishonesty , but acquitted the applicant of the aggravated fraud . ORG ordered that one of the defendants should not have to pay damages . It upheld ORG decision in respect of the applicant and CARDINAL other defendants , but limited the damages to be paid by those CARDINAL to FIM CARDINAL,CARDINAL each . In addition , ORG convicted the applicant and another defendant to pay , with joint liability , ORG CARDINAL based on the claim of the bankruptcy estate , which claim ORG had dismissed .
The applicant sought leave to appeal to ORG ( korkein oikeus , högsta domstolen ) which , on DATE , granted such leave concerning ORG order for damages to be paid by the CARDINAL co - defendants .

On DATE ORG gave its judgment and lifted ORG order in so far as it concerned the limitation of the damages to be paid by the co - defendants to the bankruptcy estate . ORG found that this issue had not been addressed before ORG and therefore ORG should not have decided it . ORG order concerning damages was thus upheld .
The relevant domestic law as in force at the relevant time may be summarised as follows :

According to LAW , section CARDINAL , of LAW ( oikeudenkäymiskaari , rättegångsbalken ) , ORG could , when necessary , hold an oral hearing where parties , witnesses and experts could be heard , and other evidence could be taken . The oral hearing could be restricted to a certain issue .

According to the domestic legislation in force at the relevant time there was no prohibition against changing the presiding judge during the proceedings . The new Criminal Procedure Act ( laki oikeudenkäynnista rikosasoissa , lag om rättegång i bråttmål ) came into force on DATE . According to LAW , LAW of that LAW , the main hearing shall be restarted in case the district court has to take on a new member due to the lack of quorum .

According to LAW the chairman and CARDINAL lay judges constitute the quorum in a district court . The lay judges have a personal vote . The presiding judge shall explain to the lay judges the issues that have arisen in the case and the provisions applicable to the issues . In case of a vote , the opinion of the majority is to prevail . In the event of a tie , the opinion more lenient to the defendant is to prevail .
